description.narrative: Instituto de Nutrición de America Central y Panama (INCAP) har lämnat in en ansökan till ambassaden i Guatemala om finansiellt stöd till genomförandet av den nationella undersökningen om mödra- och barnhälsa ”Encuesta Nacional de Salud Materno Infantil/ENSMI” 2013. ENSMI har sedan år 1987 genomförts i Guatemala och Sverige har gett stöd till genomförandet av enkäten år 2002 och 2008/2009 med ett totalt belopp av SEK 24 000 000. Det totala beloppet av svenskt stöd som föreslås till genomförandet av ENSMI 2013 -2014 uppgår till SEK 14 000 000.

The purpose of the study is the use of demographic data for monitoring maternal, neonatal and reproductive health across time. The specific objectives are: • To provide state institutions, national and international actors with demographic information and analysis, • Increased available information for the international audience on Guatemalan demographic characteristics, • To provide up-dated disaggregated information on reproductive health for women and men.

participating-org.narrative: INCAP/Instituto de Nutricion de Centro America y Panama

Reproductive, Maternal, Newborn and Child Health (RMNCH)

description.narrative: General question: Results related to the intended outcome 2016Question: Summarise results related to the intended outcome (this information will be sent to Open Aid)Answer: The National Survey on Maternal and Infant Health ENSMI is considered a fundamental statistical Survey in Guatemala to document the situation, changes and tendencies over time related to maternal and child health, which is among the worst globally. The Survey provides important statistical information and orientation toward public policy formulation to reduce child mortality, eradicate extreme poverty and hunger, improve maternal health, and to combat HIV/Aids, malaria and other illnesses. The indicators used to recollect information document, for example, women's access to education, fertility rate, family planning practises, child mortality and mother-child health. The sixth edition of ENSMI suffered serious delays in implementation and production, mainly due to the complex administrative, technical and financial set-up to carry out the Survey. Ministry of Health and Social Provision of Guatemala does not have the technical capacity or necessary funds to carry out the Survey, whereby the Ministry depends on external actors and donors to carry out the Survey. Changes of Ministers of Health, of Governments and Officials responsible to oversee the process have all impacted in delaying the Survey. Additionally, labour and personnel conflicts between the Technical Director in Guatemala and his employer MACRO/DHS had negative implications on timely delivery and final cost of the Survey. As of December 2016, VI ENSMI has been approved and validated by the Ministry of Health whereby publication of the Survey can be expected in the following months. Since the Survey has not been made public yet, the intended outcome of increasing access and quality of health services was not achieved during the Swedish support period. Given that there is considerable interest among donor countries supporting health sector to have access to the Survey for decision-making, and a Minister of Health concerned about improving quality of public health services, the final outcome of providing an instrument to design public health policy can be expected to be achieved once the Survey is made public.
No indicator available - only a description of the activity results is published
